awd_titl_txt: Theory and Methods for Causal Inference in Chronic Diseases
awd_abstract_narration:
Chronic diseases such as cardiovascular disease and HIV create an immense health and economic burden, both within the USA and globally.  With recent technological advances, the chronic disease research enterprise is rapidly becoming data-intensive and data-driven.  Massive and complex data provide unprecedented opportunities for discovering optimal treatment strategies for chronic diseases. However, these complex data also present novel challenges for statistical analysis.  Patients may visit the clinic at irregular intervals, may drop out of studies, and may discontinue prescribed treatments prematurely. In addition, there may be "confounding by indication", in that some treatments may have been prescribed preferentially to sicker patients.  These features can be barriers to effectively translating rich information into meaningful knowledge. The overarching theme of this project is to develop new data analysis methods that tackle these important and recurring challenges. This work aims to advance statistical science through the development of novel approaches to address these difficult challenges, where existing methods do not apply or suffer from major drawbacks. The research will also provide subject matter scientists with a principled way to approach scientific questions in these settings to discover optimal treatment strategies for patients.   

This research project has the following goals. 1) Develop estimators of survival distributions as a function of time to treatment discontinuation using a dynamic-regime marginal structural models approach. Treatment discontinuation arises frequently in clinical practice, complicating the analysis and interpretation.  The objective here is to develop an instructive demonstration of how careful conceptualization of this problem leads to an unambiguous definition of a sensible treatment effect and to valid inferences, shaping a principled approach to dealing with treatment discontinuation.  2) Develop efficient estimators for Structural Nested Mean Models (SNMMs) from longitudinal observational studies in the presence of informative censoring using semiparametric theory. Time-varying confounding by indication is a widespread phenomenon and causes selection bias in the estimation of treatment effect.  SNMMs have been proposed to overcome this issue; however, their use in practice is still unpopular, partly because the efficiency of the estimators is highly dependent on the choice of estimating equations, and the theory is still underdeveloped in many settings.  The investigator plans to develop improved estimators of causal parameters in SNMMs in the presence of censoring, which gain both efficiency and robustness to nuisance model specification over existing methods.  3) Develop a new framework of continuous-time SNMMs. In many realistic situations, the outcomes and treatments are more likely to be measured at irregularly spaced time points. Most of the existing SNMMs literature uses a discrete-time setup, which is overly simplified and therefore impractical. The investigator aims to provide a unified framework for SNMMs with continuous-time processes, establishing a novel area of research in causal inference.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Chronic diseases such as cardiovascular diseases (CVD) and HIV produce immense health and economic burdens in the USA and globally. With the advance of technologies, the chronic disease research enterprise is rapidly becoming data-intensive and data-driven. Indeed, massive data provide unprecedented opportunities for discovering optimal treatment strategies for chronic diseases. However, complex data also present novel challenges for statistical analysis. Patients may visit the clinic at irregular intervals, may drop out of studies, and may discontinue prescribed treatments prematurely. In addition, there may be "confounding by indication" in that some treatments might have been prescribed preferentially to sicker patients. These features can be barriers to effectively translating rich information into meaningful knowledge. The major contributions of this project are new data analysis methods that tackle these important and recurring challenges for causal inference in big observational studies, handling missing data, time-varying confounding, and complex data structures.

Intellectual Merits: Yang and Ding (2018) addressed causal inference with observational studies trimmed by propensity scores. Yang (2018) proposed doubly robust weighting estimators for causal inference with clustered data. Yang and Kim (2018) investigated asymptotic properties of nearest neighbor imputation estimators. Yang and Zeng (2019) discussed different doubly robust strategies, including weighting, regression imputation, and g-estimation. Corder and Yang (2020) and Dong et al. (2020) investigated imputation methods for causal inference and individualized treatment learning. Yang, Wang and Ding (2019), Li et al. (2020), and Kong et al. (2021) developed methods for causal inference and Z-estimation with non-ignorable missingness. Huang and Yang (2022) proposed dimension reduction tools for robust inference of treatment effect heterogeneity. Reich et al. (2020) reviewed causal inference methods for environmental and epidemiological applications. Yang, Kim and Song (2020); Yang, Zeng and Wang (2020a;b); Yang and Ding (2020); Yang and Kim (2020); Yang et al. (2021) developed a series of works that leverage multiple heterogeneous data sources to improve finite population inference and causal inference. Yang et al. (2018); Yang, Pieper and Cools (2020); Yang, Pieper and Cools (2019) and Cools et al. (2021) developed continuous-time causal models for continuous and survival outcomes, respectively. The PI has authored 30 research publications under the support of her NSF grant, and some additional works are under review or revision.

Broader Impacts: R packages based on the newly developed causal inference methods are available at the PI's Github repository along with demo examples and Comprehensive R Archive Network (CRAN); see, e.g., contTimeCausal. The PI provided numerous research talks at workshops, conferences, and colloquium seminars. The PI has actively participated in the SAMSI (Statistical and Applied Mathematical Sciences Institute) programs as a faculty fellow from 2018 to 2021 and led working groups for the 2020 Causal Inference program with themes on medical and health applications. The PI also organized a BIRS 5-day workshop, ?Emerging Challenges for Statistics and Data Sciences: Complex Data with Missingness, Measurement Errors, and High Dimensionality,? from May 22?27, 2022, at the UBC Okanagan, Canada, bringing statisticians, computer and data scientists, and practitioners together to share current research advances and form new collaborations. The PI has been working with 22 Ph.D. students (12 female), and 5 (3 female) students have completed their dissertations with selected chapters on causal inference. The collaboration with medical doctors and health data scientists led to new insights into the improved treatment strategies of oral anticoagulation for patients with atrial fibrillation (Cools et al., 2021), contributing to relieving the disease burden.
